title: Reciprocity Project
subject: English
description: This is a semester/yearlong class project that explores reciprocity in Stó:lō culture. A main objective of this project is to create a sense of community within the classroom.

title: Storytelling Unit
subject: English
description: This lesson plan introduces students to Sxwōxwiyám through listening and reading activities. It includes a template for students to illustrate their own book based on a Sxwōxwiyám. The Sxwōxwiyám included in this lesson are 'How Wolf Turned into Killer Whale' and 'Story of the Cedar Tree.'

title: Sqwélqwel Lesson
subject: English
description: This lesson plan introduces students to Sqwélqwel and the difference between Sqwélqwel and Sxwōxwiyám. It includes a video interview with a Seabird Elder who tells a Sqwélqwel, a take-home activity, and an opportunity to share with the class.

title: Sxwōxwiyám Lesson
subject: English
description: This lesson plan introduces students to Sxwōxwiyám through the telling of the story titled “Beaver and Eagle Bring Fire” by Mr. And Mrs. Johnny Bobb.

title: Shxweli Writing Exercise
subject: English
description: This lesson plan teaches students about the Stó:lō concept of Shxwelí. It defines Shxwelí, teaches students about homographs, recounts the Sxwōxwiyám of Lhilheqey (otherwise known as Mount Cheam), and closes with a writing activity.

title: First Peoples - Who Gets to Draw the Maps
subject: English
description: This lesson uses an article written by Indigenous author Lee Maracle, a video of Seabird Island elders, and class discussions to teach students about the intersections between story, place and power.

title: Family Identity Shoebox Project
subject: English
description: This project explores themes of identity and storytelling. It helps students connect with their family history and community identity and creates space to share that with the class.

title: Indigenous Identity in Pop Culture
subject: English
description: This lesson takes an estimated 9-11 days and explores Indigenous self-representation as a form of seeking justice.

title: First Nations People – A Trilogy
subject: English
description: This is an 80-minute lesson that uses the play titled “First Nations People: A Trilogy” to teach students how literature can help them make connections with their surroundings and better understand themselves.

title: Mural Analysis Project Plan
subject: English
description: This versatile lesson plan has the potential to be used in English, English First Peoples, or Art classes. Depending on the subject, this mural lesson explores themes such as community identity, justice, self-representation, and/or the power of art, graphic design, and writing.

title: Journal Writing Prompts
subject: English
description: This lesson plan provides various writing prompts that encourage introspection and reflection on themes like identity and upbringing.

title: Novel Study Activities for The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian’
subject: English
description: This lesson plan provides novel study activities for students reading the book “The Absolutely True Diaries of a Part-Time Indian” by Sherman Alexie. It promotes exploration of themes such as ambition, family obligation, and identity.

title: First People's - Poetry Unit
subject: English
description: This unit explores using place in poetry to cultivate a sense of belonging.

title: Homeostasis
subject: Bio
description: This lesson explores the factors that affect homeostasis in riparian environments.

title: Model Organ System
subject: Bio
description: This lesson features a model organ demonstration and aims to teach students about the structure and function of different organ systems.

title: Homeostasis in Riparian Species
subject: Bio
description: This lesson explores homeostasis in riparian species. It is a multi-part lesson that includes an introduction to riparian zones, research and analysis of human impact on the environment, restoration strategies and solutions, and activity-based research and reflection.

title: Water Quality
subject: Chemistry
description: This lesson explores the effects of water manipulation on water quality.

title: Simple Machines
subject: Physics
description: This 5-part unit introduces physics concepts through the exploration of the Stó:lō people’s use of simple machines such as levers, wedges and inclined planes.

title: Xwelitem Lesson
subject: Science
description: This lesson explores Stó:lō teachings from elders and members of the Seabird Island community relating to gathering resources and harvesting responsibly. It also introduces the term Xwelítem, which was the name given to settlers by the Stó:lō people.

title: Characteristics and Habitat of Trees
subject: Science
description: This lesson plan teaches students about biodiversity and includes an activity on tree bark identification. It also includes the red cedar Sxwōxwiyám as told by Frank Malloway. This lesson was designed to fit into a unit on biodiversity and characteristics of plants. It is recommended that it comes after a lesson on the parts of a tree.

title: Chinook Salmon in the Maria Slough
subject: English
description: This lesson and activity teaches students about chinook salmon and their significance in Stó:lō culture. It includes information on the anatomy and life cycles of chinook salmon.

title: Maria Slough (Sqémelech) - Erosion, Degradation, Habitat Loss and Conservation
subject: Science
description: This lesson plan covers topics such as wetlands, erosion, riparian zones and conservation. It requires multiple in person visits to the Maria Slough.

title: Fishing
subject: Science
description: This lesson explores Stó:lō fishing practices and the impact that climate, environmental, social, and political change has had on traditional practices.

title: Pandemics & Epidemics Unit
subject: Science
description: This 5-part unit begins with an exploration of pandemics, epidemics, how diseases spread, the 1782 smallpox epidemic, the 1862 smallpox epidemic, and smallpox on Seabird Island. It includes a variety of informational videos, activities, experiments, and interviews from Seabird elders.

title: Cells and Cellular Processes
subject: Science
description: This 1–2-week lesson explores cells and cellular processes through a study of algae and microorganisms in water.

title: Exploring Aquatic and Riparian species
subject: Science
description: This lesson requires students to observe and compare aquatic and riparian species in order to identify and contrast their characteristics. This activity will aid students in understanding the diversity of life forms and their adaptations in different environments.

title: Photosynthesize
subject: Science
description: In this lesson students will learn about photosynthesis, transpiration, and the power of sunlight. This will be accompanied by a discussion of XeXa:ls and the stories of how they “made the world right” through transformation.

title: Circle of Life - Exploring Interconnectedness
subject: Science
description: This lesson and its activities seek to help students recognize the significance of Indigenous knowledge and perspectives, specifically in relation to conversations around sustainable living.

title: Climate Change
subject: Science
description: This lesson explores the effects of climate change over the centuries through a discussion of physical changes on Seabird Island due to glaciation and human actions.

title: Human Impacts on Climate Change
subject: Science
description: This lesson explores climate change and its impact on severe weather events. It includes a class visit to the site of the 2021 landslide on the east end of Seabird Island.

title: Nitrogen Cycle and Salmon
subject: Science
description: The objective of this short lesson is to understand the nitrogen cycle and its impact on salmon and salmon habitats.

title: Genetics Through Family History
subject: Science
description: This lesson explores DNA as the basis for the diversity in all living things through discussions of concepts like mutations, inheritance, dominant and recessive genes and genotypes and phenotypes. It also includes biographical profile videos of seabird elders and a family history project.

title: Disease as an imbalance in Homeostasis
subject: Science
description: This lesson seeks to aid students in understanding the concept of homeostasis and its connection to disease through the lens of the smallpox epidemic among the Stó:lō. This lesson also encourages students to explore the causes and consequences of the epidemic and encourages empathy for those affected by it.

title: Stólō Plant Use Project
subject: Science
description: This versatile lesson plan can be adapted to a variety of grades and subjects. It explores local plants and their use and significance in Stó:lō culture. This lesson plan includes a guided nature walk where students can learn about local foliage, seeds, and the planting process. This lesson plan also includes a comprehensive chart with pictures of plants, their English, Latin and Halq'eméylem name, and their medical (or other) use.

title: Listening to the Water
subject: English
description: This lesson plan introduces students to Sqwélqwel and the difference between Sqwélqwel and Sxwōxwiyám. It includes a video interview with a Seabird Elder who tells a Sqwélqwel, a take-home activity, and an opportunity to share with the class.

title: The Changing River Activity
subject: Science
description: This short 1-hour lesson uses images of the Fraser River over the years to help students understand how rivers change over time.

title: Story Graph Lesson
subject: Math
description: This lesson plan teaches students about story graphs using a journal entry from a journey taken up the Fraser River by an Anglican missionary and his Stó:lō guides in 1858. The lesson plan also includes a Sqwélqwel about a whirlpool as told by Fred Ewen.

title: Cause and Consequence, The CPR
subject: Social Studies
description: This unit includes 5, 30-minute lessons. It explores how the Canadian Pacific Railway (CPR) was an important factor in B.C. joining confederation. It also explores how the CPR impacted the history of Seabird Island.

title: Wind Drying Salmon
subject: Social Studies
description: This lesson plan includes content and direction for using it in both a grade 4 and grade 9 social studies classroom. It discusses the history of the Stó:lō and the continuing impacts of imperialism and colonialism in B.C. through an exploration of the cultural practice of wind drying salmon.

title: A Xwelmexw World
subject: Social Studies
description: This unit takes an in-depth look at Stó:lō life (social, economic, political and spiritual) through the lens of the Longhouse. It also discusses the considerable and irreversible impact of the arrival of foreigners on Stó:lō land.

title: Natural Resources and Conservation Project
subject: Social Studies
description: This lesson plan has the potential to be used for multiple grade levels and subjects. It includes a project that involves students selecting a natural feature of Seabird Island and researching the ways that feature has changed over the last 100 years.

title: BC and Confederation - The CPR and Seabird Island
subject: Social Studies
description: This short lesson plan asks students to consider the impacts of the CPR on Seabird Island.

title: Geography of Seabird Island Project
subject: Social Studies
description: This lesson plan explores the physical and human geography of Seabird Island. It encourages students to notice and appreciate the place they live, learn, and play in.

title: WW2 Indigenous Involvement and Veterans
subject: World History
description: This 4–5 day lesson plan explores the experiences of Indigenous people in and after WWII. It includes excerpts from a novel and a poem, a carousel activity, and an in-depth look at the story of a Seabird Island veteran.
